Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 02:27PM Gottobme wrote: atlanta01 - I'm very sorry if you took what I said as criticism.  It wasn't meant that way at all.  Believe me, I honestly do understand how you feel about 9 weeks being a rediculous period of time to wait.  Diagnostic services being done in a timely manner is only good medicine.  My commenting on our educating ourselves is in regards to that being the only control we have sometimes.  The 'I want it done yesterday' is a totally normal response to the abnormal wait times that holds us hostage to our fear of the unknown.  There are pit falls on both sides of the boarder with healthcare.  We'll always be fighting an uphill battle for change frustrating as it is to admit that. I hope you are able to have that time line brought up through a cancellation if nothing else.  Hoping the best for you.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 10:46AM Gottobme wrote: Everything started for me May 8th when I went to a walk in.. Had ultrasound guided biopsy May 12th and went for results May 23rd.  Saw surgeon July 4th, had post biopsy ultrasound July 14th.  Will have surgery Sept. 13th. Atlanta01 - Chickenpants has it right, use the time to educate yourself.  It really helps, I did the same and am not panicing about my long wait time for the excisional in Sept.  I've been told the tumor is B9 and am not too worried even if something is uncovered that couldn't be detected.  Putting this in prospective aint easy at first but with educated knowledge of breast cancer and reading the experiences of the sisters here with breast cancer. It makes the wait a little more tolerable. I wouldn't say that because we don't pay for our healthcare that it's not a very good standard.  Long wait times are a headache but I feel most provinces try and address important issues that directly affect patient care.
Posts.Title: Would you wait 2-3 weeks for a biopsy? Beanpole DocBabs

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 08:43PM Gottobme wrote: Like amandamarsh, I was no great fan of the biopsy either.  I found it uncomfortable for the same reason.  But, the pain goes away really fast and not everyone feels much at all.  For discomfort later, I used the lill ice pack they fixed me up with for wearing home.  I was given written instructions on care of the biopsy site and you can't even see the scar now. The biopsy was totally unexpected so I didn't think to ask if my husband who was in a main waiting area could come in.  But it didn't take long and the radiologist told me what he was doing and just kept talking really. Good luck
Posts.Title: Preparing for biopsy Lavender250 Gottobme

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 04:57PM Gottobme wrote: Hi Tj, Just wanted to check in and see how you were.  Treat yourself to a little TLC, it won't hurt one bit. Hope the biopsy went without issue.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 11:46AM Gottobme wrote: I've been diagnosed with cancer (not breast) before and over the years have delt with the emotional side of chasing this cancer (melanoma) pretty well.  But there are people who don't get what the worry of diagnostic testing brings or they say, 'oh, if it's cancer, you'll be just fine really, it's nothing these days'. Yes, there many very good treatments for breast and other cancers now but it's the feeling that your fears aren't or shouldn't be validated and that you should just suck it up. OH REALLY!!!!  Now we all know that breast cancer is in the spot light quite often.  But, even with that, so many people don't get it.  Some want to and others don't.  You soon learn the people to keep close and those who should be kept at a distance if bothered with at all.  There's nothing easy about the diagnostic process emontionally.  I liken my emotions to being up and down like a toilet seat.  Not knowing is the hardest part of this and that's very understood here.  Be kind to yourself and don't push how your feeling out of the picture.  Coming here allows for emotional and very practical support. Thinking of you, let us know how your doing.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 01:38PM Gottobme wrote: Wow, I just got a call from the surgeons office, they are going to call me with the results instead of me waiting.  The surgeon said I had already been through enough with everything that happened on Tuesday and he didn't think I needed a longer wait time to deal with on top.  It will still be 7 to 10 days, but better then 5 weeks.  YAY!!! Kimmer, fingers crossed you get a better answer for your wait time as well.
Posts.Title: Got report. Birads 4. What does it mean? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 09:15PM Gottobme wrote: Well kimmer, I got you beat unfortunately, I get to wait 5 weeks.  First, the surgeon is away and just as he gets back, his secretary is away.  I just keep reminding myself that the path report for the biopsy in May came back B9 even with a birads 5.  I also feel that because the freezing wasn't working great and that it may have prevented the surgeon going as deep, my path report might get done before the office shuts down.  I do really feel it's B9 as the first path report says partly because the radiologist who did the wire guide said things looked calmer then when I had the first biopsy.  The ducts weren't inflamed around the tumor like they were in May.  Ok, I realize it doesn't excuse bad planning on the part of the surgeon and I can call my GP for results too. On your question about birads 4, mine was birads 5 because the papilloma was surrounded by dense tissue and there was scar tissue.  There was too much going on but it turned out to be B9 even with a higher birads.   Wishing you the best for a B9 outcome and keeping you in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Got report. Birads 4. What does it mean? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 05:25AM Gottobme wrote: Hi Kimmer, I can only go by what happened when I had the biopsy in May.  When the radiologist was doing the biopsy, he and the tech couldn't believe how fast the tumor kept filling in with blood with each sample taken.  He told me I would continue to bleed from the nipple after the biopsy.  As it turned out I didn't but, I did have alot of swelling and very dark nasty bruising.  From the time of the biopsy, I did have some sharp pain through the nipple and breast up until the surgery last Tuesday. There is only regular bruising with the excisional and today some uncomfortable but, manageable pain. Call your dr on Monday anyway just to be sure.  When I saw the surgeon for the first time in July, I told him the breast still hurt.  He told me it can take 3 months to properly heal from the biopsy.  I feel the healing is going better with the surgery then it did with the biopsy. Look at your instructions for care post biopsy and see if anything suggested there might help with the pain.  Take it easy too hon.  Yes a biopsy is minor surgery but preasure and movement can cause issues. Take it easy, hope your dr can help.  Hugs
Posts.Title: Blood leaking from nipple 6 days after core biopsy? Normal? Kimmer1975 Lifes-A-Beach

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 07:54AM Gottobme wrote: Hey Kimmer, I PM'd you. :)
Posts.Title: Blood leaking from nipple 6 days after core biopsy? Normal? Kimmer1975 Lifes-A-Beach

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 12:35AM - edited Sep 19, 2011 12:37AM by Gottobme Hi Kimmer, I really like telehealth, it's a port in a storm on weekends. Lifting and such can cause discomfort too and that might have just agrivated things a little.  I did have alot of discomfort in my under arm and I noticed it because my summer tops rubbed on that side.  Now they don't.  Ya, I was told, no alcahol and no anti inflamitories like asprin and ibprofen (?sp) and such.  As for me, I'm still trying to wrap my head around what happened.  Difficult intubation is handled by intubating the patient while they are awake so certain meds don't have to be used that make it easier for intubation.  They didn't follow the protocol from the last time where I was semi awake and I think they will have to answer to their boss for that cause he set that protocol for me.  And as to why the local freezing didn't work that great....That ment the surgeon couldn't go as deep as he wanted.   So I'm really not feeling great emotionally.  What happrened to me has so many implacations in regards to any future surgery I may need and I'm having trouble coming to terms with that.  Then there's waiting for the results from the excisional.  I know, I know, it's *very* unlikely it won't come back B9 but I'm not feeling too confident about anything right now.  Sorry for dumping on your thread Kimmer, didn't mean too. You don't need anymore to worry about either girl. :)  Let us know how your doing and what the doc says.  Hugs
Posts.Title: Blood leaking from nipple 6 days after core biopsy? Normal? Kimmer1975 Lifes-A-Beach

Posts.Content: Gottobme wrote: I called the surgeons office this morning and spoke with the secretary.  She was really good and answered my questions and said that if I had any questions between now and the surgery, to call the office. The surgeon says not to stress but wants to remove the papilloma (which I know, is often the practice) with this kind of tumor.  Ummm, don't stress, sure, no problem......NOT.  I have cerebral palsy so staying still for the wire location should be really interesting as I sometimes have spastic movement.  He wants a general used which is ok but I have to have concious intubation cause 2 years ago, my airway completely closed and they couldn't even get the fibre-optic scope in so, they started a trech and the airway opened as the incision for the trech was made. I have a good time line and don't have to rush into the OR so that's good.  I know I'm on the good side of diagnosis so I'm not complaining at all.  I'm more concerned about external issues regarding me rather then cancer.  If there is cancer then, I'll deal with it but my heart on that score is with those of you living with your diagnosis of cancer.  Either way, CP plus being visually impaired, any surgery bites and my 6 month check up for melanoma is on Monday so I'm not entirely happy and for that I apologize for any poor pitty mees I might come out with between now and surgery.  We are in a heat wive in southern Ontario and I have no air con so, I'm off to a friends place to keep cool.  Hugs  Smiles are like rocks, we reach out for them to save us from the raging river of emotions. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Having wire guided excisional Gottobme VSM

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 03:16PM Gottobme wrote: Thank you for responding.  I have just found out that my best friends mom has been restaged from IDC stage 1 to IDC stage 3.  My heart goes out to my friends mom and my friend because her mom is pushing her away right now and isn't ready for her help yet.  I told her that her mom needs time to adjust and my friend wants to be there yesterday for her.  I have suggested my friend come here for support and suggestions on how she can help her mom when her mom is ready. She said she has taken a look on the site. As I said, she is my best friend and she made it very clear that she wants to be involved in being there with me at my surgery along with my husband.  I feel odd about that now because mine is a non-invasive (compared to her mom) surgery with little chance of there being cancer at all. I am fine and it's just not fair that others have to go through so much.  Thanks again, I'll let you know how things go on Monday.  I'm not worried but with bothe my husband and I being visually impaired, it takes more visits to the doctor to keep an eye on me regarding melanoma.  Take care and have a wonderful weekend.
Posts.Title: Having wire guided excisional Gottobme VSM

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 10:20AM Gottobme wrote: VSM, You are indeed right.  When things aren't what they should be, alarm bells sound and we are off and running with the what ifs and what might bes. Resulting in our energy and our sense of wellness being held hostage by the unknown. I very quickly learned about papillomas once I knew that's what I was dealing with and am not too worried about it.  But it's the turn you take from regular breast care to what's going on that everyone needs support with for sure and I thank you for your support.  Because of the cerebral palsy, I can't examine my breasts properly so any extra monitoring will be good.  But that 'the doctor wants to take a look then, we're doing a biopsy now' was a heart stopper for me. amandabu,  I really appreciate you telling me about your experience, thanks for letting me know how you did post op.  I had pretty much figured what happened with you would be the coarse for me too.  The curve ball for me was the surgeon wanting to use a general.  But mostly, it's the wire guide procedure that I'm kinda wondering about with me having some spastic movement but, we'll get that worked out.  My papilloma could only be seen on ultrasound so I think that's how the wire guide will be done too.  Because of my left side being affected with the CP, I rely on my right arm for just about everything including movement.  With the surgery being on the right breast at the 8 o,clock mark,  I'm a little concerned on how the healing will go. I have learned so much about the road some of my other sisters must travel down and I want most of all for them to have their road lit with the light that is born of knowledge and places to stop and rest that have come to be there from love and support Hugs and thank you.  Now to go murder a few icecubes by drowning them in a glass of water.  I will show no mercy.  It is quite hot in our part of Ontario.
Posts.Title: Having wire guided excisional Gottobme VSM

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 10:05AM Gottobme wrote: Just got back from my doc that deals with the melanoma and all is ok but instead of a 6 month check up, she wants me back in Nov. Still waiting for the surgeons office to call back with confirmed surgery date and pre-op for the removal of the papilloma.  As it isn't urgent, I asked for Sept. for the surgery and the secretary said that time line was fine so I'll know soon. My friends mom has great support from family and friends so, she is feeling not too bad.  She is waiting for more tests to see where she goes from here.  She doesn't have a computer but has phone numbers she can call to talk to someone who can answer question about her kind and stage of BC and give her peer supprt too. Keeping you in my thoughts... Hugs
Posts.Title: Having wire guided excisional Gottobme VSM

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 07:07PM Gottobme wrote: Radiologist did the biopsy and a general surgeon is doing the surgery. As cycle-path said, choosing a radiologist who isn't isolated is best. Although, not as easy to do where I live so, I had to wait for results. If you are referred to a surgeon,  do research on any surgeons recommended.  I researched the surgeon my GP recommended and, most of his practice is cancer and he does alot of breast surgery. However, he is not listed as a surgical oncologist but rather as a general surgeon because he does do other areas of surgery as well.  The reviews on my surgeon from patients he has treated were very favorable. Some general surgeons do not limit what they do.  Regardless, I look any mds up even though my GP is great at referring me to excellent specialists. My surgeon is also connected to our regional cancer center and that helps if answers are needed quickly.  The radiologist was with a breast clinic.  As I said though, sometimes where you live might affect when you get results. Best wishes
Posts.Title: general or breast surgeon for biopsy 1flowergirl1 Gottobme

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2011 08:46AM Gottobme wrote: The thing is, we are very very relieved, grateful, thankful, for it not being cancer.  Who wouldn't be.  But sometimes, it's the 'I knew you'd be ok, didin't I tell you' comment that makes you feel like you went into this for attention.  Rather then the supportive comments of relief that it's ok.  Here's the thing, it's never 'nothing'  It's always 'something' that came under the radar.  But for some of us, the 'something' is ok.  Depending on their health or family hystory, some are worried about the next 'something' that might come along. They are worried and it should be respected. As a cancer survivor , I'm very careful how I tell those who find out they don't actually have melanoma that, it's the best news. It could come across as being very dismissive of their fear of it being cancer.  You don't know if that person is already feeling like they are going to be accused of "crying wolf" and over reacting. One of the many grate things about this board is that, the ladies with breast cancer *don't* make us feel like our fears are rediculous and totally unwarranted.  Cautioning (as the ladies here do),against worry, is totally different then dismissing  that fear of 'something'.
Posts.Title: Ever been treated like you've "Cried Wolf"? :( Rushell Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 05:34PM Gottobme wrote: That's wonderful Kimmer.  It means more then can be said to have them beside us.  My first husband told me it was my fault I had cancer.  I now have a very supportive DH who will be there with me on Tuesday for the wire guided excisional. He is my rock and, I count myself as being very fortunate to have him in my life. Keeping you in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: My Hubby is such a stinker!!!!!! Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Gottobme wrote: I had a mammagram (my first) in Feb and a cyst was found on left breast and confirmed by a follow up utrasound a couple of weeks later and I thought all was done until 2013.  Then, on May 5th started bleeding from the nipple on the right breast.  Nothing more happened until the 7th so on the 8th, I went to urgent care thinking it might be an infection but after blood work and breast examination, I was told it wasn't and to go to my Dr.  As I waited fo the Dr to come back, the bleeding started up again so, they sent me to the breast screening clinic in the same building.  The same one the mammagram had been done in.  They told me to come back that Friday when the Dr would be there to have an ultrsound done of the right breast. Tech did the ultrasound and the Dr came in and said there was a lesion and did a biopsy.  Got the results on May 24 and here's where my problem is. My Dr said that the report was conffusing in that, the path report came back not cancer and he closed the file on it so to speak.  Then, the radiology report came back and he said the histology wasn't good.  He stopped me in mid sentence and said, this is serious, you have to see a surgeon about your breast.  That's when he said I fall between the cracks.  So, maybe I shouldn't even be here but where does some one like me go.  I have been dealing with melanoma for 25 years and am very grateful that my situation with this isn't anything like that of those who are diagnosed with BC.  But, I am concerned and don't know where to go with this.  I tried to get him to read the reports but he looked like he was in a round room trying to find a corner.  Sorry if I'm in the wrong place but, I thought I would start here.  I have an appt. with a surgeon on July 4th to start the process of dealing with this lesion.  To add to this, my best friends mom was just diagnosed with BC.  So I feel bad for my friend and her mom who was knocked sideways by her diagnoses.  I am in Ontario so I'm not sure how long this will take for her or for me.  It doesn't help that I saw my Dr Tues and got my appt with the surgeon by Friday.  My friend is worried because her mom hadn't heard yet when she is to see the surgeon.  I told my friend that her mom will most likely be seen and a treatment plan in place b4 I see the surgeon in July. Hope it's ok that I posted here. :)   Smiles are like rocks, we reach out for them to save us from the raging river of emotions. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I fall between the cracks Gottobme Gottobme

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 01:17PM Gottobme wrote: First, thank you for the wonderful posts of good wishes.  I have a benign papilloma that at the top, looks like it is just scar tissue but further into the tumor, is a papilloma.  I have seen the surgeon who is great but he wanted another ultrasound because it has been 2 months since the biopsy.  The ultrasound was done yesterday and, it's a small lesion but was findable and the tech commented that the ducts were inflamed at the time of biopsy and that they are better now.  I'm most likely looking at excision of the tumor but don't know until I meet with the surgeon again.  I had a rough time with recovery from the biopsy.  Even last week, I had swelling and pain and when I mentioned to the surgeon that it seemed to be taking awhile to settle down, he said it could be 3 months.  I have cerebral palsy on my left side and have to rely on right side (the side the tumor is on), for support and cannot hold much in my left hand.  That may be having an impact on recovery.  Given that there are ladies dealing with much more invasive breast surgery, I can't understand why such a small biopsy caused the problems it did.  I'm used to biopsies but I was surprised when I felt pain during the procedure over the tumor but not on the margins. I'll know where I'm going with this once I see the surgeon.  But given recovery from the biopsy didn't go as I thought it should have, I'm a little concerned regarding surgery.  It's so stupid because it's a small procedure but I am concerned about recovery from surgery.   I continue to support my friend who's mom has BC and pray that all turns out well for her and her family.  I go for my 6 month check up for melanoma in a week.  I had 3 lesions removed in Dec. and hope all is quiet on the westron front at this next visit. Again, thanks to everyone for your support.
Posts.Title: I fall between the cracks Gottobme Gottobme

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 08:48PM Gottobme wrote: Well..... It's ok to put me first sometimes. It's good to let others help. It's wonderful to know how much others love you and how important you are to them and, how valuable their support is to you. It's not weakness to be scared. It's good to cry and even better to laugh. It's time to allow for forgiveness and to be forgiving in turn. It's wonderful to be blessed with the knowledge that nothing is for granted and to appreciate what we have and who we are. Hugs to all.
Posts.Title: What is your positive out of this negative situation? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 06:07PM Gottobme wrote: Hope your mom gets the all clear hon.  Mine was visiting when I had the excisional and I told her that she didn't have exclusive rights to worrying.  I told her what I was concerned about with her and told her that because I'm not living close, I do worry about her and that it's normal for kids to worry about their parents. It can be frustrating when we only want the best for them but hey, they are our moms and I'm sure they felt the same when we were kids and we made them worry. LOL   I can still hear the, 'get home before dark', 'phone me when you get there' and the best, 'don't go out without clean underwear on'.  No matter how old we are, they worry about us though and will still say that they, know best cause they're mom.
Posts.Title: Frustrated with my Mom. Any advice? Kimmer1975 kristysvn

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 09:04AM Gottobme wrote: I had a core biopsy and I was told, no asprin based drugs or alcohol either.  Tylenol was ok and ice.  Hope they are able to do the stereotatic this time.
Posts.Title: Pre-biopsy instructions JodyJ Gottobme

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 04:32PM Gottobme wrote: JodyJ - Yes thank you, all turned out well with final excisional biopsy coming back solitary B9 papilloma. The core biopsy came back with the same but the papilloma was in dense tissue so the surgeon didn't want to second guess anything. I got the final results on Monday GreenSeaTurtle - That's very interesting about fish oils and vitamin E.  I have had many excisional biopsies for melanoma and have noticed lately that I bleed easier now post surgery.  Not open flow just need to do more wound care now.  Hmmmm, I intended talking to my doc about that when I'm next in.  I'm going to mention this, thanks.  I don't take either but, it's got me thinking that there might be soemthing else in my diet that's causing the issues I'm having.
Posts.Title: Pre-biopsy instructions JodyJ Gottobme

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 04:51PM Gottobme wrote: Good to hear that you got the all clear.  It's frustrating when the people we are supposed to go to for help, don't always know what information to give us.  Add to that the difficulty of finding a family doctor.  I am very thankful that I have had the same doc for 18 years. I'm with you about posting questions here.    I have told a few people about this site including my melanoma doc.  Hope you haven't had the rotten cold that has been making friends around here.
Posts.Title: Follow up US post B9 Biopsy! Kimmer1975 Gottobme

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2011 08:31PM Gottobme wrote: In answer to the melanoma - no recurrences, satellite tumors. I went 10 years without anything.  But recently have had *new* moles coming back positive for melanoma. Thanks for the info, I'll let you know what the doc says.
Posts.Title: Pre-biopsy instructions JodyJ Gottobme

Posts.Content: Gottobme wrote: Since joining this site, I have mentioned my best friends mom having been restaged from IDC stage 1 to IDC stage 3 and how my friend wants to be there to support her mom.  My friend has been pushed away and she has been confused and hurt by her moms actions.  I and others have told her that her mom needs time.  Well, on Friday, her mom called her and asked her if she would like to come with her, her other sister and her moms husband when she gets the results of tests she is having over the next 2 weeks.  Needless to say, my friend was so relieved to be able to be there for her mom now.    Her mom and I started our journey at the same time and I am having trouble with the fact that I got the news we all pray for and she did not.  The unfairness is so hard and you can't do anything to make it go away or to have it never happened.  So I give support to my friend who welcomes it even though I was the one who is ok and not her mom.  The hurry up and wait is made easier when you have someone who cares and understands.  I feel privileged to be a part of the support network and am there for as long as I'm welcome to be.  But I wish oh, how I wish this could be different. Smiles are like rocks, we reach out for them to save us from the raging river of emotions. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My best friends mom Gottobme Rushell
